componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. My name is Doris and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Gap Inc. Fourth Quarter 2011 Conference call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your host, Katrina O'Connell, Vice President of Investor Relations.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to Gap Inc.'s Fourth Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. For those of you participating in the webcast, please turn to Slides 2 and 3.I'd like to remind you that the information made available on this webcast and con
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to Gap Inc.'s Fourth Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. For those of you participating in the webcast, please turn to Slides 2 and 3.
I'd like to remind you that the information made available on this webcast and conference call contains forward-looking statements. For information on factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements, as well as reconciliations of measures we are required to reconcile to GAAP financial measures, please refer to today's press release, as well as our most recent annual report on Form 10-K, and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q. all of which are available on gapinc.com.
These forward-looking statements are based on information as of February 23, 2012, and we assume no obligation to publicly update or revise our forward-looking statements. Joining us today on the call today are Chairman and CEO, Glenn Murphy; and Executive Vice President and CFO, Sabrina Simmons.
Now I'd like now I'd like to turn the call over to Glenn.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katrina, and good afternoon, everybody. In a few minutes, I'll hand the conference over to Sabrina, who'll take you through 2011 highlights and also talk to you about our guidance and some key metrics for 2012. So before we get to that, I want
componenttext:
Thank you, Katrina, and good afternoon, everybody. In a few minutes, I'll hand the conference over to Sabrina, who'll take you through 2011 highlights and also talk to you about our guidance and some key metrics for 2012. So before we get to that, I want to take you through a couple of thoughts I had on this past year and also talk to you about where I see 2012 in terms of the company's strategic plan and what investments we see ourselves making in the upcoming year. In spite of 2011 earnings being below last year, we actually did make quite a bit of progress against our strategic plan. So we have 2 key initiatives that Gap Inc. has been pursuing over the last 4 years that make up our strategic plan.
The first key initiative is to reduce our dependency on our North American specialty bricks and mortar business. So we did accomplish quite a bit on that front in 2011. First off, we grew our online business and penetration to our total sales by 2 percentage points. Second thing we did, we reduced our specialty square footage by over 4% while at the same time growing our outlet square footage domestically by 4%. We closed 65 stores domestically and we opened up 8 Athleta stores, very successful, I may add, and that makes us feel very good about our future for 2012 and beyond.
The second area which we made quite a bit of progress is our move to expand our brand internationally. At the beginning of the year, we operated in 31 countries combination of franchised and company-owned stores, and we ended 2011 by operating in 39 countries. In China, we opened 10 stores and finished the year with 14 stores and feel very good about the progress we're making in China, particularly in Hong Kong. And in 2012, we have a plan right now to open 30 stores. Franchise business where we opened 50 stores and good performance were seen in our franchise business and we grew total year 2011 at greater than 40%, and we see an opportunity to open at least 50 stores in 2012. We added global outlet into Italy, in Japan, in the U.K. and will be taken our global outlet business to China in the fall of 2012.
And lastly, Banana Republic opened up in Paris is into Champs-Élysées beautiful store and that will be the beginning of Banana Republic expanding into France. As we go come into 2012, our goal clearly is to advance our strategic plan at this fiscal year while at the same time improving our sales and earnings profile of the corporation. So in order to ensure success, one of my key mandates for 2011 was to make sure the business took appropriate corrective measures in some key areas to make sure we can deliver on that latter goal of improving our sales and earnings profile of 2012.
So there's 4 areas that we've been focused on in the last fiscal year: product, our assortment, our marketing and our supply chain. So let me first talk about product. Probably the biggest change we made throughout the year in 2011 was the creation of the GAAP Global Creative Center in New York City. That was bringing together from the domestic and international perspective design, marketing and production to create one amazing hub of creativity to New York City for all of our stores around the world. And really the first output from that team just showed up in our stores globally 2 weeks ago. I really like the progress I've seen that Pam Wallack's leadership in New York. The other changes have been quite a bit of investment in people that we started to make through the year and continue to make going forward. The first one that came out was the creation of this creative advisor goal. Tracy Gardner joined us about 4 weeks ago. We just announced that Jill Stanton will be creative advisor of note Old Navy. Jill has an amazing background in Next, Marks & Spencer and Nike globally.
This is a new role but it's critical to me to get to consistent product execution. One of the conclusions we came to through years is we need to add this role to work with our designers integrate a nice bridge between the design teams and the merchandising teams. So really quite a bit of development along product. With everything we're doing, the goal is clear here. We need to have consistent product execution every quarter, every year across our brands.
We focus on assortment at the latter part of 2011. Probably driven by the spike in cotton pricing in value businesses. We got a little off balance between basics and fashion, and also we got a little bit off between our opening price point product and our best product. Those changes have been made, and Old Navy's assortment will be much better balance between the areas I talked about between April and May.
Marketing was quite a bit of work in 2011. I'm really excited. When I look at all of our brands, we are either starting the year with a brand new marketing platform or a modified platform in order to make sure we got a great return for our marketing and really drive brand equity and traffic. So Old Navy, we modified the  platform that we introduced in November. The real modification the product shows us that if it's a great platform. It's so Old Navy as well as it should. Those modifications are being made.
Brand-new platform at Gap came out 2 weeks ago. right. It's a global campaign and really think we have a great idea. Banana Republic you'll see in the marketing that came out this spring will focus on what you're calling internally new work. The marketing is about that. It's showing up on the windows. It's showing up in-store. How does Banana Republic as it did a decade ago redefine what work is. And Athleta came up with a brand new platform called power to the sheet. Very appropriate for the Athleta business as we add from our 10 stores we currently have and add 25 new stores in 2012. The campaign is going to be so important for them.
And lastly, we made some adjustments to our supply chain. We brought our distribution and logistics team together brought and merged it with our sourcing team to create 1 supply chain team, lead by Colin Funnel, our Executive Vice President of Supply Chain. Same time, we also changed how we go to market. For years, we've had a geographically-based hub structure and we've moved to category teams, and we've added a lot of talent. New leadership in India, new leadership in Hong Kong. That's critical to make sure our supply chain efforts in 2012 and beyond really bring great value to the Corporation.
And lastly, as I do every year on the February call, I have to talk about the investments the company wants to make in 2012. Once again, the support its strategic plan. SG&A, to me, has 2 really distinct components inside of it. There's a fixed company which companies to spend every single year and there's a variable component. And the time we spend as a management team is always discussing in advance of a new year where we're going to place our bets, where we're going to best money, not only to achieve our strategic plan but get a great return to drive sales and earnings inside the business. Examples of that were in 2010 where the highlights of that year were about China, about global online.
Last year, we talked about opening up Italy and expanding our and Athleta business. So as we enter 2012, we're going to continue with our International expansion. But what you're going to hear a little differently is we're going to have a focus on putting some money back into our Domestic business in 3 key areas: in product, in marketing and in e-commerce.
On about up front, like a lot of other people in the industry, we expect to get some tailwinds in our cost of goods in the second half of 2012. So we made some decisions that we're going to make some investments very targeted, very specific in categories we know we can dominate on, but we can get a point of differentiation redefined. And really what the focus for me is categories I believe assets for the corporation. And so that's been the filter we're using. We want to make sure we get savings from the reduction of costs. We're going to make some targeted investments that's really going to benefit our Domestic business. So key categories in Banana Republic, Old Navy and in Gap brand is investment we're going to make in 2012. We're going to put some money behind Gap brand marketing. The time is right. We really believe in our team in the Gap Global Creative Center. And we're going to be putting somebody behind marketing for the new platform called  around the world but the real focus here in North America. I think our  team has done a lot of work in 2011 to position them, not only to drive our brand equity, but to make sure we're out there telling customers about it week in, week out, months in and month out, season in and season out. That's very important for 
And lastly, we're going to put some money as we have, really, the last couple of years but even stepped up amount behind our e-commerce business. We opened up a new distribution center in 2011. So we're going to have those costs to carryforward for all of 2012. But the real investment is in mobile. Our mobile platform has done extremely well. We have a lot of new ideas, innovative ideas, coming out from Toby and his team.
And the last area, which is really about global, is we're going to create a brand-new, global IT platform. Now when you open up in Italy and China and some of the plans we have for the business going forward, you have to be strong in IT, you have to be strong in supply chain. It's going to take us a number of years to get done to really create and build a brand-new global IT platform. So we enter 2012, everybody here at Gap, Inc. very focused on what we have to get done. We know what needs to be done and now we're very motivated as we come into the year to make sure that we take all of our brands to a new level and perform well domestically and internationally across every brand, every channel and every geography.
So with that said, let me hand it over to Sabrina who will take you through the financial highlights and I've been at them back after that and answer any questions from the analysts. Sabrina?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Glenn. Good afternoon, everyone. I'll begin today with a review of our fourth quarter and full-year results and then provide an overview of our outlook for 2012. Although 2011 was a challenging year, it's worth pointing out some bright spots in
componenttext:
Thank you, Glenn. Good afternoon, everyone. I'll begin today with a review of our fourth quarter and full-year results and then provide an overview of our outlook for 2012. Although 2011 was a challenging year, it's worth pointing out some bright spots in our performance.
Throughout the year, we delivered higher average unit retail, enabled by our disciplined inventory management. While continuing to invest in our long-term growth initiatives, we tightly managed our operating expenses which leveraged 30 basis points. We generated $800 million in free cash flow, and finally, we distributed $2.3 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
Please turn to Slide 4 for our earnings recap. In the fourth quarter, net earnings were $218 million and earnings per share were $0.44. Full-year net earnings were $833 million and full-year earnings per share was $1.56, down 17%.
Turning to Slide 5, sales performance. Fourth quarter total sales were $4.3 billion, down 2%. Full-year total sales were down 1% to $14.5 billion, and comparable sales, which include the associated comparable online sales, were down 4% for the year. Total sales and comps by division are listed in our press release.
Turning to Slide 6, gross profit. Since Q1 of 2011, we laid out our view that margins would contract significantly during the year, driven by the sharp escalation in average unit costs, especially in the back half. Further, we also said that we would deliver average unit retail up, but not up enough to offset the increase in average unit cost. The year did indeed play out this way. For the fourth quarter, gross margin was down 540 basis points to 32.8%. Merchandise margins were down 500 basis points while rent and occupancy deleveraged by 40 basis points. Gross profit was $1.4 billion.
For the full year, gross margin was 36.2%, down 400 basis points. Merchandise margins were down 370 basis points, and rent and occupancy deleveraged by 30 basis points. Gross profit for the year was $5.3 billion, down 10%.
Turning to inventory on Slide 7. Given the high average unit cost this year, we managed our inventory units down so that our total inventory dollars per store remained reasonable. We're pleased that at the end of the fourth quarter, as indicated on our January sales press release, inventory per store in terms of dollars was about flat.
Please turn to Slide 8 for operating expenses. Given the decline in our gross margin dollars, we responded to mitigate the impact to earnings by managing our expenses tightly. And even as we continued to invest meaningfully in our International growth initiative, we leveraged Q4 operating expenses by 60 basis points.
For the fourth quarter, total operating expenses were $1 billion. These expenses include $166 million of marketing, up slightly to last year. For the full year, total operating expenses were $3.8 billion, down $85 million from the prior year and leveraged as a percent of sales by 30 basis points. Full-year marketing expenses were $548 million, up $32 million for last year.
Please turn to Slide 9 for capital expenditures. Full-year capital expenditures were $548 million, focused on International and the associated IT investment, Global Online and Old Navy downsizes. In line with our articulated strategy, in North America, we continued to reduce our square footage through closures and consolidations of Gap brand and downsizes at Old Navy. For the year, we closed 65 stores on a net basis and decreased square footage by 1.3 million square feet in North America. Outside of North America, we grew through both company-operated and franchise stores.
On a net basis, we added 33 International company-operated stores and 49 franchised stores. Total Gap Inc. net square footage was down 2.6% compared to last year. Store count and square footage by division are listed in our press release.
Regarding cash on Slide 10. We generated strong cash free flow, defined as cash from operations less capital expenditures, of $800 million, and we repurchased 111 million shares for $2.1 billion at an average price of $18.88. Our level of share repurchase for the year was higher than usual, enabled by our capital raising in the first quarter of 2011. We ended the year with 485 million shares outstanding.
Now I'd like to share with you our outlook for 2012. Please turn to Slide 11. We expect earnings per share for fiscal year 2012, which includes the 53rd week, to be in the range of $1.75 to $1.80, and operating margin to be about 10%. Underlying that guidance are the following priorities: improving sales with healthy merchandise margins; investing in our business while maintaining disciplined; and returning excess cash to shareholders.
With regard to improving sales and delivering healthy merchandise margins. It's our objective to drive modest top line growth through the stabilization of our base businesses and a continuation of our global growth initiative which are focused on our online outlet and franchise channels.
Moving to margins. Clearly, cotton inflation had a significant impact on our average unit cost in 2011. As is commonly known in the sector, spring 2012 costs are up, though up less than holiday 2011. We are fairly confident that average unit costs will be improve in the second half of 2012. However, we've just begun to purchase the back half and are still finalizing our assortment and reinvestment decisions. Therefore, some uncertainty exists regarding exists regarding precisely where costing will land.
Our second priority is investing in our businesses while maintaining discipline. As Glenn discussed, After 5 years of extremely disciplined expense management, coupled with a focus on International growth, we are going to be investing more in our domestic businesses. As a result of that, it's unlikely we will leverage operating expenses in 2012.
We'll obviously temper the level of investments depending upon our momentum and our likely return and we will update you as we proceed through the year. With regard to inventory, we plan to continue to manage inventory units in a disciplined manner and expect inventory dollars per store to be about flat at the end of Q1. Our third priority is returning cash to shareholders. As I mentioned, our 2011 share repurchases were higher than usual due to our capital raising. In 2012, we expect to return to a more normalized pace of share repurchases. And today, we announced a $1 billion share repurchase authorization.
In addition, we plan to increase our annual dividend by $0.05 to $0.50 per share, representing a payout of nearly 30% of net earnings.
Please turn to Slide 12 for a summary of the guidance I just provided and some additional full-year 2012 metrics. Regarding company-operated stores. Net of repositions, we plan to open about 125 stores and close about 115. Store openings are weighted toward International and outlets, while store closures are weighted towards Gap specialty stores in North America. We expect net square footage to decrease by about 1%. We expect capital expenditures to be about $600 million, and depreciation and amortization to be about $475 million. And finally, we expect our full year effective tax rate to be about 39.5%.
In conclusion, as we enter a new year, we're committed to growing earnings per share while strategically reinvesting in the business. Thank you. And now, I'll turn it over to Katrina.

componenttext: There was a lot in there. What I would say is that we talked in the opening comments about a number of things: one, we are making some investments in our product. And again, We're being selective, we're being targeted, we're making some key categories across our brands. And then what probably wasn't clear in the opening comments, then if you do that, that's part of the driver as to why you're seeing us put a little more marketing money into our domestic business because if you're going to do that, we have to out into the window, in-store, through social media, through other tools to let people know let people know that we have either done base investments in key categories like suiting up Banana Republic and there's list of categories we believe across all our brand. I believe that's going to generate some tension from customers and turn into traffic for our store. So just one area in which were doing now. In terms of promotional activity, I think that we're always challenging our team's and last year was not necessarily our best year on this front. We were much better at this 2010. It's funny to be innovative, really differentiated marketing, value proposition that bring people into the stores. If you look at something Old Navy started in 2012 was called Super Cash. I think ideas like that, that Gap can have a version Banana Republic, after that and, of course, Old Navy and our outlet stores need always find was innovative, what's unique, what does a customer really respond to? I think those 2 things in combination should be enough to at least give us an improvement on the traffic trajectory that we were disappointed in and 2011.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I guess, all I'd add, Christine, on the inventory front as I mentioned in my remarks, we do want to deliver modest top line growth with healthy margins. So that means we really want to watch our inventory and keep it tightly managed. And we'll continu
componenttext: And I guess, all I'd add, Christine, on the inventory front as I mentioned in my remarks, we do want to deliver modest top line growth with healthy margins. So that means we really want to watch our inventory and keep it tightly managed. And we'll continue to do so as the year progresses. It will be a great thing if we end up having to chase some inventory because demand begins exceeding the inventories we have. But we'll see how that goes. But the intention is to definitely deliver healthy margins and keep the inventory tightly managed.

That takes a while, and there's tools out there. We've actually developer our own proprietary tools in some cases develop to be able to speak to people directly and not just to rely on broadcast media. So that also may be affecting your bias.

The reason we're not articulating a precise amount because quite frankly, the amount and pacing of some of that spend is really going to flex and depend on our momentum and our confidence in the product, in the momentum of the business and that those investments would deliver a return. So a lot of this has yet to unfold. I hope what you can count on is on us is to manage all of those levers responsibly and our commitment is really around delivering on that EPS range we put out there.

componenttext: I can't comment directly on how it's performing inside the store. What I can say is that -- and I could take an exhaustive answer here and go brand by brand but it was commented at the beginning of the call on product. The change be made in New York City was that was a seismic shift for us. Because it really is bringing together the last pic design teams, the International design teams under one full global design team in New York City for Gap. So that team worked for about 10 months together. They worked through processes and we have to make sure we're all lined global aesthetic and there was work to be done. We all agreed 2011 was not our best foot forward at Gap. So that work just showed up in the store February 10, little bit later in some of our global markets but February 10 in North America. Then there's a lot in there that I feel good about. The work from in terms of the talent and bringing together those 2 teams, then the addition of the creative advisor role under Tracy. I'm starting to see at least, and I was in New York just recently, how they're working together, what decisions from a fashion and basic, the balance of the assortment, and the decisions those teams are making. I think they're really crystal-clear on the aesthetic going forward. The Banana Republic team, they start going through, not the same seismic shift that went on at Gap, but they addressed some of their content Women's and opposite number that helped the Banana Republic team have a 6 comp January. I believe they've been on top of making the changes they needed to make about 6 months ago. And there's some similar changes going on at Old Navy. So all in all, with the trends in the marketplace which are really highlighted by a real focus on color and demand of color, given our brands and what the American aesthetically stand for and the work that we've done corrective measures. Because the keepsake internally that anybody can good as can have a good month. We don't want to perform well and above where we've been which is our commitment based on the fact we're just lucky on a trend. We just want to make changes in the business that affect our business performance.

componenttextpreview: My question is regarding the International business. It's obviously a key strategic priority that you're clearly excited about. Huge, global opportunity. Can you help us appreciate how -- some of the metrics that you're seeing with your International busi
componenttext: My question is regarding the International business. It's obviously a key strategic priority that you're clearly excited about. Huge, global opportunity. Can you help us appreciate how -- some of the metrics that you're seeing with your International business, how it's performing, how some of the comp classes have been doing for us to really get excited about the promise as we move throughout the years?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Roxanne, I'd say 2011 was a bit of a mixed bag. So if I start at the top, what we feel very good about our franchise business. And we opened up in 8 new countries in 2011. We had greater than 45% growth, 50 stores. And as Sabrina mentioned in our comments
componenttext: Roxanne, I'd say 2011 was a bit of a mixed bag. So if I start at the top, what we feel very good about our franchise business. And we opened up in 8 new countries in 2011. We had greater than 45% growth, 50 stores. And as Sabrina mentioned in our comments, we'll do at least 50 stores in 2012. So I feel very good franchise teems, our franchisees, so that's one piece. China it also feel very good about. 14 stores operating, 30 more stores to open in 2012. Open in Hong Kong in November was a very successful opening for us. Open in 2 other cities, Tianjian and Hangzhou, we're now in 5 cities in China, 5 more cities to happen close to 2012 with 10 cities which operated also feel very good. Japanese businesses, it's difficult for us to gauge given the incredible disaster they ceased in 3/11 last year, we have a big business in Japan, all the better sense of that coming into later in the spring and in the summer. But I like what the team is doing. I think -- happen to know that were being done in the Gap Global Creative Center is resonating well because the Japanese team. Some of the product has not gone to our customer yet but our team likes what they're seeing. Our Banana Republic businesses is going to probably the expand by a few stores in 2012. That's been on hold for a few years. I think that's good news and we'll open up Old Navy Japan on July 15, just outside of Tokyo. That leaves us with Europe. And our European business, like a lot of other companies, was soft in 2011. The team there was very aware of it. We have a small business in Italy. So really, what we're talking about for us is France and the U.K. Austerity measures were tough, we're not good enough in 2011. The product global at Gap Women's that hurt our overall global Gap business, particularly hit our business in Europe hard, did not register at all with the customers. Again, payments product in the European markets which we operate. So too soon to tell. That's going to be a tough market. That's a wait-and-see for us. We're going to be very careful on capital, be very careful on investments. We still believe in Europe, but we're going to be watching it quite closely the next 12 months.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of Ed Yruma.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Ed Yruma.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: This will be the last amount of square footage growth, or excuse me, the, the square footage you've had and some period of time. Is it fair to say that, at this point, you feel like you're store closure program is mostly complete? And if you provide a lit
componenttext: This will be the last amount of square footage growth, or excuse me, the, the square footage you've had and some period of time. Is it fair to say that, at this point, you feel like you're store closure program is mostly complete? And if you provide a little bit of color specifically on Old Navy, I know you've been tweaking the format there and shrinking some of the stores and maybe some the performance there as well.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ed, it's Sabrina. I'll take that. We're very much on track with the strategies we've laid out the last couple of years. So just as a reminder, the strategy around Old Navy is to downsize a lot of our stores as we remodel them into the new remodeled format
componenttext: Ed, it's Sabrina. I'll take that. We're very much on track with the strategies we've laid out the last couple of years. So just as a reminder, the strategy around Old Navy is to downsize a lot of our stores as we remodel them into the new remodeled format. And we're making good progress there. So 2007, we had 20 million square feet. We ended it this year, 2011, with 18.1 million square feet. We'll be shedding about another 400,000 square feet in '12. So we should end around 17.7. And that's really on track with what we laid out back in October to get to 17.5 in '13. With regard to Gap specialty, same. Right on track. We said we wanted to get to 700 stores by 2013. We'll be closing about 85 stores in North America specialty in '12, get us down to about 750. And at the same time, important other side of the strategy is to grow the Gap outlets in North America. So we'll be opening about 20 of those. So net-net, we're right on strategy. And then we have the International stores coming up, and that's why the square footage decline isn't as great.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Jeff Black with Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Jeff Black with Citi Investment Research.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of things, just a clarification, Glenn. When you say you're -- now is the time to invest in marketing, do you think the lack of marketing was in someway a huge hindrance to last year's comps? Are you saying that you think the product is just bett
componenttext: A couple of things, just a clarification, Glenn. When you say you're -- now is the time to invest in marketing, do you think the lack of marketing was in someway a huge hindrance to last year's comps? Are you saying that you think the product is just better and could benefit from better marketing? And the question on sourcing is where are the lead times, where are you in terms of using your hub strategy of the differently and are both of these things better set this year so a little tailwind might be turned into a significant tailwind that we get some lower than you see then you guys are projecting?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Jeff, on the marketing side, it's definitely the latter, where the time is -- we tried to say in an earlier answer, just because we have maybe 1 season that sits in a showroom that's about to be produced AUC again to the stores that would never get us wor
componenttext: Jeff, on the marketing side, it's definitely the latter, where the time is -- we tried to say in an earlier answer, just because we have maybe 1 season that sits in a showroom that's about to be produced AUC again to the stores that would never get us working behind product. We've worked very hard, as we should've, given our performance in 2011. Worked really hard in the product front in getting clarity in each one of our design teams, whether that's addition of talent or it was just a better focus and part of that was the GC, the Gap Global Creative Center in New York City. And the confidence has picked up to a point where some market, I want to make sure I'm clear on this, some marketing will go into Q1. The investments I'm talking about will have to be the one earned and they will happen at probably if our business performs at the higher rate through the year. So it's driven by, if you're going to be making some changes in product and get it right on to the customer in which we need to attract our stores, you've got to go tell that story. We have a lot of marketing in the business. I want to make sure I'm clear about that. So it's a Gap story mostly in domestic, mostly in North America. Old Navy had plenty of marketing. Their issue in 2011 was it wasn't effective, as we said a number of times on these calls, maybe aren't as transparent as we are. We were not happy with our marketing up until November when the new platform came out. On the sourcing, the team is just being put together now. We were very pleased with our geographical hub structure up until 2011. Could've made the change then to a more category structure versus aligning all the way through our business from design to merchandising through production through sourcing by categories. But given the spike in cotton, we decided to not do with at that time because we have enough disruptions going on, enough stress in the business to try to manage our way through that challenge. We're in the early days, Jeff. Let's see. This is the month of February. So the team that's been put in place from a category perspective, they're first in back in the business will probably our holiday buying which we haven't even begun just yet. So they'll probably have some impact on holidays. The real benefit to me of the category hub structure, it allows us to build a much deeper relationships with the mills upstream which we do not have today. That's a missed opportunity in our sourcing. We do the old mills. we will going forward in the category structure hub and the category leader relationship with the mills much stronger. And I think some of that benefit that I hope won't be materialized could come in the holiday but most of that will be 2013.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from the line of John Morris with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your next question is from the line of John Morris with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask with respect, Glenn, to the domestic reinvestment that you're talking about, the emphasis on that -- in the 3 areas: marketing, product and e-commerce. Will one of those be emphasized more or will it be balanced? And Sabrina, on that topic
componenttext: I wanted to ask with respect, Glenn, to the domestic reinvestment that you're talking about, the emphasis on that -- in the 3 areas: marketing, product and e-commerce. Will one of those be emphasized more or will it be balanced? And Sabrina, on that topic, it sounds like a lot of that will be coming from some of the recaptured savings from the lower AUC in the back half. And would you say that most of that potential differential, that delta, is going into that domestic reinvestment?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's probably -- I'll try to handle both and then I'll pass it over to Sabrina for some comments at the end. I'd say John, it's difficult to be absolute about this because we have flexibility. Product is one area we're going to invest in. Again, it's go
componenttext: That's probably -- I'll try to handle both and then I'll pass it over to Sabrina for some comments at the end. I'd say John, it's difficult to be absolute about this because we have flexibility. Product is one area we're going to invest in. Again, it's going to be very targeted in key categories and that we can dominate in selective brands. That's one of the longest lead times. So I would say that one, as I know today, will likely be the most amount of pure dollars will go into that area. But we also -- we've done some tests ahead of time, some categories, to make sure we can resonate with customers. It will be noticed and we get paid for it. But we will be watching it through the year to make sure that those that that outcome actually happens. Marketing would be the next one in line but that has much more flexibility, much shorter lead times. And e-commerce, I talked about the new Phoenix distribution center where got up in full operation in the fall of 2011. There's some mobile investments out there that may get some investments in people that goes into that business as well. And probably the lesser of the money we are spending as we do every year stated in the beginning, we are always decide what variables as G&A we want to put in the business to deliver the strategic plan but also to hit the framework of the economic model the company needs to have. In terms of what percent we'll build, here's what they'll tell you: we're and that best, just finishing our fall buy right now. We haven't even started ending on holiday. We had choices like we have across all of the centers in business. One, negotiate as hard as we as we can which is regarded do regardless, and get savings through the assumption of tailwinds at the back half to pull all of that money in the bottom line of the business. But also we had it choice of pack and go. Where do we believe? We can actually get a win in certain key categories across brands and give our designers and merchandisers a little bit of license to put some our money back into product and just one last point on that. When you take a product, to me, it starts with fit, which was no more money. Just want to have great fit them consistently good than the ghost politico doesn't cost any money you got to have the right color for the season. Then it goes to style which should be print and pattern as well. It doesn't cost any more money then we get the fabric. So our designers and merchants know that in order to have excellent, consistent great product season in, season out, you to deliver on all 4 of those. All we're trying to highlight today is there are some areas putting money back to the fabric does make strategic sense to us.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question is from the line of Richard Jaffe with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question is from the line of Richard Jaffe with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow up on the sourcing change and then a question for the franchise goals longer-term. First for the purpose sourcing, obviously, I've been spoke strategy Glenn is an old one and one that's well-entrenched within the company. And the chang
componenttext: Just a quick follow up on the sourcing change and then a question for the franchise goals longer-term. First for the purpose sourcing, obviously, I've been spoke strategy Glenn is an old one and one that's well-entrenched within the company. And the change you suggested category or more of a, I guess, vertical by product initiative. It sounds like that's going to be at leased a year-long process or multiyear process to get that fully implemented. Is that correct? Or is it in place today and it's just a question of timing to the product in stores?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: What I'm saying to, Jeff, I'm actually going up to all our sourcing offices next month to have a much better feeling than when I got out. But our teams will be in place and will be actually executing our holiday category structure we have in place. My poi
componenttext: What I'm saying to, Jeff, I'm actually going up to all our sourcing offices next month to have a much better feeling than when I got out. But our teams will be in place and will be actually executing our holiday category structure we have in place. My point to Jeff was that the full benefit, the full value unlock for the company of going from design, all the way to the continuum of our product, all the way to sourcing and then our sourcing team working with a better balance of the mills and vendors, that'll probably -- that value unlock will probably take place in 2013. But the team executed our product, sourcing and negotiations and vendor relations will be on a category basis starting this holiday.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And Glenn, will that include 2013, that is to say, will that includes taking fabric positions or commitments on fabric?
componenttext: And Glenn, will that include 2013, that is to say, will that includes taking fabric positions or commitments on fabric?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're actually -- we do some fabric platforming today, not as much as I think we should. We have some work to be done there and we, not only under Collin's leadership, which is a fresh set of buys but 2 senior executives part of his new team he's but toge
componenttext: We're actually -- we do some fabric platforming today, not as much as I think we should. We have some work to be done there and we, not only under Collin's leadership, which is a fresh set of buys but 2 senior executives part of his new team he's but together. I believe all of them have and have in many conversations over the last 3 months with males, with our own in-house teams about the benefit of fabric platforming, the long term, the cost-benefit, the speed benefit, which is really what I want to get because that's where the gross margin comes if you can get fabric platforming on speed. In terms of the franchise business, we presented, it must've been 2 years ago, that we plan on having 400 franchised stores by the end of 2013. We're definitely on track for that. We feel good about that goal. Stephen Sunnucks and his International team, or Steven in particular, representing International team will be available in October, like he is every single year, to give an update on everything International. But I suspect that he will be able to get an update number of franchised stores at that time.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And does that include the southern hemisphere?
componenttext: And does that include the southern hemisphere?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, that's x Brazil, x India.
componenttext: No, that's x Brazil, x India.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And any thoughts on that hemisphere or those countries?
componenttext: And any thoughts on that hemisphere or those countries?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. We've had many trips to Brazil. We like the Brazilian market. The capacity there is very difficult, capacity in terms of square footage available is difficult in Brazil. I'm actually going for the 6th time to India this March besides the sourcing team
componenttext: No. We've had many trips to Brazil. We like the Brazilian market. The capacity there is very difficult, capacity in terms of square footage available is difficult in Brazil. I'm actually going for the 6th time to India this March besides the sourcing team I'm spending time with the Indian teams. So I'll get a sense of those. So those are 2 markets that of course, we will be targeting down the road. And Steve, once again, October, to give an update on what our thoughts are on those 2 big markets.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Stacy Pak with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Stacy Pak with Barclays Capital.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: So Sabrina, my question's really is for you. What does the guidance embed in terms of AUC recapture in the second half of '12? I mean, I heard what you said about you're not sure exactly what you're going to get but what are you embedding in your guidance
componenttext: So Sabrina, my question's really is for you. What does the guidance embed in terms of AUC recapture in the second half of '12? I mean, I heard what you said about you're not sure exactly what you're going to get but what are you embedding in your guidance? I'm assuming you have some recapture in there. And if not, why not? And should be sort of assume there is? And also, what is your guidance embed in terms of share repurchases? Something similar to Q4 run rate? Is that what's in there?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll try and be helpful. Obviously, we put out a range, Stacy. So we do lots of scenarios. And the range that we've guided to is the best reflection of what we believe are the most probable outcomes with the info we have today. So there are a rang
componenttext: Yes. So I'll try and be helpful. Obviously, we put out a range, Stacy. So we do lots of scenarios. And the range that we've guided to is the best reflection of what we believe are the most probable outcomes with the info we have today. So there are a range of scenarios for both AUC, and just as a reminder, what I said was we are fairly confident we will get costing improvement in the back half. There still is uncertainty because we said, and Glenn just reminded, we just started buying the back half. And this allowed some decisions not only the variables that are macro factors like cotton and labor and all of that, but there's also just our merchants who are making decisions about the mix of assortment, where they'll reinvest. But all that said, we think we're fairly confident caught and that costing will improve in the back half and our range includes scenarios with improvements. With regard to share repurchase, we also have embedded a range of share repurchases. Now I think it's important that I just underscore, again, we're trying to signal that we are absolutely committed to cash distributions as we have been for many, many years. Nothing in our principal has changed. But definitely, 2012 will be a more normalized, what we consider normalized year share repurchases. And if you look back over the last whatever, 6, 7 years, we sort of averaged $1 billion, $1.3 billion per year. And the timing obviously, matters about those share repurchases and now accretive they are in their back-half-weighted, front half weighted, et cetera.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And just a follow-up, Sabrina, on the AUC, is part of what you been talking about in terms of investing in the product upgrading the fabric, is that taking away some of the AUC benefit that you would otherwise see?
componenttext: Right. And just a follow-up, Sabrina, on the AUC, is part of what you been talking about in terms of investing in the product upgrading the fabric, is that taking away some of the AUC benefit that you would otherwise see?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, reinvesting means you would get less than doing exact like-for-like AUC, definitely. Now what will also be important to manage during the year is we would like to see getting paid for those investments. And that's why we're taking our tim
componenttext: Well, obviously, reinvesting means you would get less than doing exact like-for-like AUC, definitely. Now what will also be important to manage during the year is we would like to see getting paid for those investments. And that's why we're taking our time in making them very carefully and in areas that we really believe are really important to the brand. So once again, is something Banana Republic stands for and that scenario we look at. Similarly denim, that's something we stand for at Gap and that's an area we look at.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And your final question is from the line of Paul Lejuez with Nomura Securities.
componenttext: And your final question is from the line of Paul Lejuez with Nomura Securities.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just talk to my last question, as it comes down, how we're thinking about the AUR side of the equation? How does that differ by brand? And then just second, can you comment on how much credit helped you this year and if you expect that to be a tailwind ap
componenttext: Just talk to my last question, as it comes down, how we're thinking about the AUR side of the equation? How does that differ by brand? And then just second, can you comment on how much credit helped you this year and if you expect that to be a tailwind apologize or headwind in F'12?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll do the second question first, Paul, and that Glenn might chime in on the first one. With regard to the credit card, I think you guys know we have a private label credit card for about 15 years. So a really, really long time. And then we've had a
componenttext: Yes, I'll do the second question first, Paul, and that Glenn might chime in on the first one. With regard to the credit card, I think you guys know we have a private label credit card for about 15 years. So a really, really long time. And then we've had a co-branded credit card we added about 5 years ago. And nothing's really changed with regard to how we report that. We've never given specific numbers but we do embed in our 10-Qs some qualitative flavor that is helpful to our expense management. We did get a nice increase in 2011 and we wouldn't expect that 10-Q that same kind of increase in '11 in '12. And the reason is '11 seems to be a really unique year with balances of our customers sort of growing. I guess, that's maybe a sign that people are getting more confident as the economy improves and stabilizes. But the loss rates have stayed pretty low. I think that's fairly unique circumstances. So we're not counting on the same level of growth in the program in '12 as we did in '11.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And the relationship between AUC and AUR, as we've been speaking for a number of years on the call, we worked hard to de-aggregate those inside the business as much as possible because they really are independent decisions that come together to formulate
componenttext: And the relationship between AUC and AUR, as we've been speaking for a number of years on the call, we worked hard to de-aggregate those inside the business as much as possible because they really are independent decisions that come together to formulate a gross margin rate to the senior merchant, but they should be independent decisions, AUC, AIR based on competition and what you want to do by categories. And the AUC pieces just, making sure that our sourcing and production teams can get us the best cost and leverage the size of the company.  I will say, Paul, that in 2011, given this unique year certainly the back half as we spoke about the significant increases in our cost of goods, our teams were much more aware of AUC. Those that had to had to price AIR, those that had to make AUR decisions were much more aware of it. The main in 2012, there's 2 components that are changing waste of my opening comments: One, from an assortment that assortment perspective at Old Navy in particular, we felt that we got a little bit off on the spreading of our price points under a good, better, best strategy best strategy. Got to look too far up the best category and that's going to be managed back up to a better balance inside good, better, best. So that's one change that is certainly happening. And then our value business, our outlet business and in Old Navy, because of the significant increases that really impacted them in 2011 in the back half, there's a few areas we cross thresholds with customers. Those adjustments are going to have to be made. And we're going to go back to we operate the business in 2010 which is really making sure that merchants are 100% focused on the value proposition in the business. And then the production team getting the best cost possible but not having the relationship be so directly affected one to the other as we did in the back half of '11, given the huge increases.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Glenn, what do you think your competitors are going to do in terms of when you get the AUC benefit? Do you think most will reinvest in the product and the fabric as you might be doing in some cases? Or we heard from other retailer today, a big one, they s
componenttext: Glenn, what do you think your competitors are going to do in terms of when you get the AUC benefit? Do you think most will reinvest in the product and the fabric as you might be doing in some cases? Or we heard from other retailer today, a big one, they seem to indicate that they'd accept a fairly lower merchandise margin and really go for share. What do you think about the landscape and how one treats the AUC benefit?

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's way too early to know and then also been is going to maybe they crossed some thresholds and they're going to have to make some adjustments. We watch our competitors very closely. There's going to be people who may felt the significant pressure
componenttext: Well, it's way too early to know and then also been is going to maybe they crossed some thresholds and they're going to have to make some adjustments. We watch our competitors very closely. There's going to be people who may felt the significant pressure in the back half of '11 maybe took too much out of their product. Ours less about going back to where it was, we try to hold our product this business we could. Ours is just strategically trying to put them put them into key categories. We're going to be a group like that. I want to remind everybody this is category that had very little inflation for the better part of 20 years. That's the first time we've seen some inflation. And the market leaders on price will be dictating a lot of this and people control the floor will be sending signals through everybody, whether they believe the price levels and whatever inflation was allowed to come through in a level in 2011 should sustain itself in 2012. I think time will tell.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mr. and is from the line of Ike Boruchow with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Mr. and is from the line of Ike Boruchow with JPMorgan.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question, I'm calling in for Brian. I know it's been harped on, but the SG&A, Sabrina, I mean, you guys have done such a phenomenal job. The last 5 years. I don't think you've grown expenses more than 0.5%. I don't know if you can help us wit
componenttext: Just a quick question, I'm calling in for Brian. I know it's been harped on, but the SG&A, Sabrina, I mean, you guys have done such a phenomenal job. The last 5 years. I don't think you've grown expenses more than 0.5%. I don't know if you can help us with the expenses and a little more color breakout advertising versus other investments is it back up weighted, front half weighted? Any other color would be helpful. It's something we haven't seen from you guys and long time.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I don't think that it's an enormous piece of our story going forward. So I want to make sure we're taking that into perspective. I think because of our history, you can count on us to continue to manage that very responsibly. We just also wa
componenttext: Well, I mean, I don't think that it's an enormous piece of our story going forward. So I want to make sure we're taking that into perspective. I think because of our history, you can count on us to continue to manage that very responsibly. We just also wanted to be transparent to your very point. After 5 years of really, really good management of expenses even as we were making really big investments internationally. We just want to put some investments in our domestic business as well. And that's likely going to have us deleveraged. So once again, the way that it will shape up, as Glenn said, our philosophy together is that we need to earn the spend. So we need to continue to see momentum. We need to feel confident we're going to get the return and so the shape of it will take form over the course of the year. But we do want to signal that it's likely deleveraged and will continue to manage responsibly.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd like to thank everyone for joining the call today. As a reminder, our earnings press release, which is available on www.gapinc.com, contains the full recap of our Q4 and full-year results as well as the forward-looking guidance that was included in Sa
componenttext: I'd like to thank everyone for joining the call today. As a reminder, our earnings press release, which is available on www.gapinc.com, contains the full recap of our Q4 and full-year results as well as the forward-looking guidance that was included in Sabrina's remarks. And as always, the Investor Relations team will be available after the call for further questions. Thank you.

headline: Gap Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
